ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This was an incredibly heady course, in which students were meant to unlearn just as much as they were to learn. The experience of taking this class was unlike many others I've taken thus far.

This course is a great course to take if you are self driven and self motivated, because a lot of it is based on how much you put in. There are no lectures and its all discussion driven, so you will only get something out of it if you actually do the readings.
Close reading philosophical texts. Reading them in tandem with one another. Leading class discussions and making sure to keep with the argument.
I feel like I have scratched the surface of learning to have philosophical conversations within a text as compared to abstracting it.

close reading
reading texts across time and genre together

I actually think I learned less about the subject material than I was hoping too, because the seminars were so guided by discussion and questions, but I suspect that is on my not being proactive enough with bringing my own questions to discussion

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The syllabus is incredibly intentional, and works well to foster thoughtful discussions. Professor Levene's approach to learning, however, often made it difficult for conversations to get off the ground, especially when discussing particularly dense material.
The instructor does not use any structure in the seminar room which can be advantageous, however, sometimes it felt as though students participation was stifled.

I admire the effort for open conversation however the course felt completely unstructured outside of knowing what to read each week. Conversations in class had no structure which led to a lot of empty, fluff thoughts and comments coming about. It was never grounded towards a particular point or relationship to anything. Our class time felt like a book club. By no means do I want to be told exactly what to think, however, there was ZERO structure or support in articulating ideas within the "book club circle."

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you are an extremely self-driven learner and do not care about grades, this is an incredibly interesting course to take. Do not expect thorough instruction, however -- that is far from Professor Levene's style.
Yes, great introduction to the higher level humanities and reading across disciplines.
No. Honestly not. There are better philosophy and writing classes at Yale.

Yes, as long as they went in understanding that their learning was going to be determined by their proactivity in discussions and would be proportional to the number of times they could re-read the texts in questionwhich everyone says, but is especially true for this class

Totally. Learned so much about forming/articulating arguments. Its definitely a case of you get out what you put in. Discussions are only good if youre reading and rereading the texts, but if you do that then theyre excellent. It requires a high level of buy in. And grading is not light by any means.
